titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Anna Catherine Bahlmann Papers Relating to Edith Wharton
Bahlmann (Anna Catherine) Papers Relating to Edith Wharton
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:26

did.unittitle: Anna Catherine Bahlmann papers relating to Edith Wharton

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers feature correspondence and personal effects relating to author Edith Wharton, including over 130 letters to Bahlmann from Wharton, dating from Bahlmann's employment to the Wharton family in 1874, as Edith's German language tutor, to 1915. The letters document a significant, long-standing relationship and shed light on Wharton's personal and literary affairs. In addition to the Wharton correspondence, there are single and small groups of letters between Bahlmann and family members, friends, and acquaintances, including William Morton Fullerton and Henry James, and a small number of third-party letters. Bahlmann's personal effects include legal and financial documents, notebooks, and writings, as well as material relating to Wharton. Other materials relating most directly to Wharton include clippings, documents on her work during the war, photographs, and postcards. Photographs consist of studio portraits of people and images of Wharton's residences. There are photographs of Wharton, Bahlmann family members, and friends, including Mary Cadwalader Jones. Wharton residences include "Reef Point" in Bar Harbour, Maine and the estate ("The Mount") in Lenox, Massachusetts.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English; some materials in French and German.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Restricted Fragile papers in Box 9 may be consulted only with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Anna Catherine Bahlmann Papers Relating to Edith Wharton is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Anna Catherine Bahlmann Papers Relating to Edith Wharton. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also Edith Wharton Collection (YCAL MSS 42).

bioghist.head: Anna Catherine Bahlmann (1849-1916) & Edith Wharton (1862-1937)
bioghist.p: Anna Catherine Bahlmann was employed as Edith Wharton's German language tutor in 1874 and later served as her governess, secretary, and literary assistant.

Edith Wharton was a major American literary figure in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries and, though she is best known as a novelist and short-story writer, she also wrote poetry and non-fictional works on interior and landscape design. Wharton was the first woman to win the Pulitzer Prize, awarded in 1921 for her novel The Age of Innocence (1920). In addition to critical and bibliographic scholarship on Wharton, summary information is available in the standard print and online resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers feature correspondence and personal papers relating chiefly to author Edith Wharton, including over 130 letters to Bahlmann from Wharton, dating from her employment with the Wharton family in 1874, as Edith's German language tutor, to 1915. The letters document a significant, long-standing relationship and shed light on Wharton's personal and literary affairs. In addition to the Wharton correspondence, there are single and small groups of letters between Bahlmann and family members, friends, and acquaintances, including William Morton Fullerton and Henry James, and a small number of third-party letters. Bahlmann's personal papers include legal and financial documents, notebooks, and writings, as well as material relating to Edith Wharton. Other materials relating directly to Wharton include clippings, documents on her efforts during the war, a pressed lily, photographs, postcards, and a small sachet. Photographs consist of studio portraits of people and images of Wharton's residences. There are photographs of Wharton, dating from 1900 to 1905, family, and friends, including Mary Cadwalader Jones and Pauline Robinson. Wharton residences include "Reef Point" in Bar Harbour, Maine, 884 Park Avenue in New York, and the estate ("The Mount") in Lenox, Massachusetts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Correspondence, 1874-1917. II. Personal Papers, 1875-1916.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: General Correspondence and Third Party Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence, contains letters to and from Anna Bahlmann and between others. General Correspondence includes single and small groups of letters between Bahlmann and family members, friends, and acquaintances, such as William Morton Fullerton and Henry James, and features over 130 letters to Bahlmann from Edith Wharton.

Bahlmann was employed as Wharton's tutor in 1874, when Edith was only 12, and later served as her secretary and literary assistant. Wharton's letters, which date from 1874 to 1915, spanning over four decades, document her reading and education, literary work and acquaintances, travels, and impressions on such topics as art, architecture, and landscape design. The letters document an important, long-standing relationship and shed light on Wharton's personal and literary affairs. The correspondence, unpublished in 2010, contains a significant number of early or youthful letters, filling a gap in Wharton's published correspondence.

Third-party correspondence, arranged alphabetically by correspondent, consists chiefly of condolence letters to Bahlmann's niece, Mrs. Charles Parker (Anna Louise Bahlmann Parker), including several letters from Wharton.

In addition to the correspondence in Series I, several autograph postcards, from Wharton and others, have been preserved in the postcard albums in Series II. Personal Papers. Cross references are provided where appropriate in the box and folder list below.
Correspondence is chiefly in English, with some letters in French and German. Many letters are accompanied by transcriptions.

did.physloc: See also: Series II. Personal Papers, Postcard albums, Boxes 5-6, folders 67-209

scopecontent.p: Includes copy of Anna Bahlmann's will

did.unittitle: Robinson, Pauline to Mrs. Charles Parker
Wharton, Edith to Mrs. Charles Parker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Personal Papers, contains Anna Bahlmann's personal papers, some of which relate to Edith Wharton.

Materials relating directly to Wharton include clippings, documents on her efforts during the war, a pressed lily, photographs, postcards, and a small sachet. Photographs consist of studio portraits of people, mostly women, and images of Wharton's residences. There are photographs of Wharton, dating from 1900 to 1905, family, and friends, including Mary Cadwalader Jones and Pauline Robinson. Wharton residences include "Reef Point" in Bar Harbour, Maine, 884 Park Avenue in New York, and the estate ("The Mount") in Lenox, Massachusetts.

Postcards, some dating from a trip Wharton and Bahlmann took to North Africa in 1914, have been removed from two albums and the order preserved. The albums have been digitized, and images of the albums and individual postcards, front and back, can be found online through Beinecke's Digital Library. Several postcards are inscribed by Wharton and others.
Anna Bahlmann's papers include legal and financial documents, notebooks, and writings.
